subject: Re: [junit] Method assertEquals
msgSnippet: ... If a dot is printed on the standard output it means that your test was successful executed (hurra!). If your test fails, an AssertionFailedError will be
messageBody:
> Assert.assertEquals("Message", expected, actual);
>
> Why is that the "Message" not getting printed on the standard output ??
> Instead a dot is printed.


If a dot is printed on the standard output it means that your test was
successful executed (hurra!).

If your test fails, an AssertionFailedError will be thrown. This
throwable will be initialized with your message. The runner (TextRunner
or SwingRunner it's not a question of runner) will catch this exception
and display your message and a standard message describing the error.

In your example:

Assert.assertEquals("my message", 1, 2);

would print something like this:

"my message assertEquals failed: expected <1> but was <2>"

The philosophy of JUnit is that you won't see anything (or almost
nothing) if everything is fine.

-Vladimir
